review.title: Properties of Answer Set Programming with Convex Generalized Atoms
review.abstract: In recent years, Answer Set Programming (ASP), logic programming under the stable model or answer set semantics, has seen several extensions by generalizing the notion of an atom in these programs: be it aggregate atoms, HEX atoms, generalized quantifiers, or abstract constraints, the idea is to have more complicated satisfaction patterns in the lattice of Herbrand interpretations than traditional, simple atoms. In this paper we refer to any of these constructs as generalized atoms. Several semantics with differing characteristics have been proposed for these extensions, rendering the big picture somewhat blurry. In this paper, we analyze the class of programs that have convex generalized atoms (originally proposed by Liu and Truszczynski in [10]) in rule bodies and show that for this class many of the proposed semantics coincide. This is an interesting result, since recently it has been shown that this class is the precise complexity boundary for the FLP semantics. We investigate whether similar results also hold for other semantics, and discuss the implications of our findings.

sections.text: In this section, we will first introduce the syntax used in the paper, which is mainly based on the notion of structures, i.e. functions that map interpretations into Boolean truth values. Then, we will introduce some semantic terms, in particular, we will characterize structures in terms of their monotonicity. Finally, we will define the two semantics analyzed in this essay, FLP and PSP.

sections.heading: 3 Exploring the Relationship between the FLP and PSP Semantics
sections.text: We will proceed in three steps: First, we will formally prove that FLP and PSP semantics are identical for programs with convex structures, and then we will turn to complexity to understand whether there can be any larger class of matching programs. We will begin in Section 3.2 with a result showing that programs without constraints have the same complexity among both FLP and PSP semantics. However, it is known that the semantics do not match for programs without constraints, and we will examine the complexity evidence to highlight the different complexity sources. These results will then be applied in Section 3.3 to identify programs with limited non-convex structures where the complexity of FLP and FLP semantics are different, and under common assumptions this also implies that programs with convex aggregates are the largest class of programs where FLP and FLPSP semantics coincide.

[9] states that many semantics (and especially FLP and PSP) "agree on [...] programs with convex aggregates," because "they can be regarded as special programs with monotonous constraints." However, since our language does not allow explicit negation, and especially since convex structures are not closed under negation, we next demonstrate more directly that FLP and PSP semantics coincide with positive and negated monotonous constraints on convex structures.
